Before I make a final release, my code is tested by other developers.
=
Those developers help me find the missing areas.

But keep in mind, if we h=
ave written a test for every conceivable
method we can come up with--someon=
e, somewhere will have a situation
where something fails to behave as expec=
ted.  Any time we have something
that does not behave as expected we have a=
 failure or bug.  Not behaving
as expected can be that it takes longer to p=
rocess than expected, the
log entry doesn't have the information expected, =
or something more
serious.

I apply agile tactics to my testcases.  That me=
ans I write what I need
when I need it.  Just like we can get stuck in anly=
sis paralysis, we can
also get stuck in testing paralysis.  I start out by =
testing what I need
to enforce.  If there is something that can obviously b=
e a sticking
point,
I will write a test for that.

However, what I am refer=
ring to with regression testing is that you
miss things.  You find that som=
ething needs to be tested that you were
not aware needed to be tested.  At =
that point, you write the testcase
that reproduces the error *before* you f=
ix it.
